message: Happy New Year! Wishing everyone in New Hampshire and around the country a 2017 filled with happiness, good health, and opportunity!
Always hard to leave the North Country!

Congresswoman Annie Kuster released the following statement on last night’s vote by House Republicans to weaken the independent nonpartisan Office of Congressional Ethics.   “It’s appalling that House Republicans' first legislative action of the new Congress is an attempt to undermine ethics oversight. Having an independent nonpartisan body investigate ethics complaints against Members of Congress is just commonsense. Our constituents sent us to Washington to work on the important issues facing our nation: growing the economy, creating jobs, and addressing the opioid addiction epidemic that’s impacting far too many. They didn’t elect us to make it easier for Members of Congress to abuse their power. I’ll oppose this measure when it comes to the full House for a vote, and I urge my colleagues to do the same.”

It’s truly an honor to represent New Hampshire’s Second Congressional District in Congress, and I’m humbled by the trust placed in me by the voters. In the new Congress, I’m once again prepared to focus on the needs of hardworking families in New Hampshire, and I stand ready to do the work expected by the people of the Granite State. We need to expand access to health care for our veterans, support families by enacting paid family leave and lowering student debt, protect small family farms, fight substance use disorder, and grow our economy. I’ll oppose efforts to roll back the progress we’ve made in recent years and work across the aisle to advance our shared interests. I’m excited to get to work with my colleagues, Senator Shaheen, Senator Hassan, and Congresswoman Shea-Porter as part of the first ever all-female all Democratic Congressional delegation.
No one should have to choose between being at the birth of their child & keeping their job. We must enact commonsense paid family leave policies.

I’m proud to be an original cosponsor of a resolution urging President-elect Trump to take measures to avoid conflicts of interest. The welfare of the American people and our nation must come before any personal business considerations.

The integrity of our elections is an issue that transcends politics. I’m encouraged by the support of both Republicans and Democrats in the Senate for careful examination of efforts by Russia to undermine our elections, and I hope we can come together behind this issue in the House. That’s why I’ve helped introduce legislation to establish a bipartisan and independent committee to investigate efforts to undermine our elections. It’s critical that we learn all we can about what type of interference took place so we can safeguard our democratic process in future elections. Read more here:

Dear Friends,  This week, New Hampshire made history as the first ever all-woman, all-Democratic Congressional delegation was sworn into office. We were not elected because we are Democrats or because we are women. We were elected because we know how to bring people together to get things done and that's exactly what we will do. I'm excited to get to work with my friends and colleagues, Senator Shaheen, Senator Hassan, and Congresswoman Shea-Porter, on the issues important to New Hampshire families. Together we will work to improve the lives of Granite Staters and stand in opposition to attempts to turn back the clock on the progress we've made.  On Tuesday, I also became the first Democrat elected to a third term representing New Hampshire's Second Congressional District. It's truly an honor to represent the Granite State in Congress, and I'm humbled by the trust voters have placed in me. In the new Congress, I am once again prepared to focus on the needs of hardworking families in the Granite State, and I stand ready to do the work expected by the people of New Hampshire. We need to expand access to health care for our veterans, support families by enacting paid family leave and lowering student debt, protect small family farms, fight substance use disorder, and grow our economy.  As always, I want to hear from you. Nothing is more important to informing my work in Washington than the people of my district. I hope you'll never hesitate to call my Washington office at (202) 225-5206 or visit my website at www.kuster.house.gov to share your thoughts, ideas, or concerns. To stay up to date on the work I am doing in Congress for our district, you can sign up for my newsletter at https://kuster.house.gov/contact/newsletter.  I look to the coming Congress with resolve and determination to fight for what's right and advance policies that benefit New Hampshire families. I know you'll join me in this effort.  Sincerely,  Annie
Congratulations to Sue Johnston of Littleton, the first person to hike the White Mountains New Hampshire Grid in a single year! More in The Concord Monitor:

Thank you Senator Jeanne Shaheen for highlighting the negative impact an irresponsible wholesale repeal of the Affordable Care Act would have on treatment for mental health and substance use disorders in New Hampshire. I’m willing to continue to work across the aisle to improve the ACA but will oppose efforts to roll back the law that will hurt thousands of Granite Staters and millions of Americans. Read more in USA TODAY:

It may only be January, but it feels like Groundhog Day, because once again extremist Republicans in Congress are waging an ideological battle against Planned Parenthood and women’s access to comprehensive reproductive healthcare. Planned Parenthood provides critical services to thousands of low-income women and families in New Hampshire, such as cancer screenings, STD/STI tests, and flu vaccines. This is an attack that has nothing to do with improving access to healthcare and would only hurt women in New Hampshire and across the country. I urge my Republican colleagues in the House to not include any provisions to defund Planned Parenthood in their proposed budget.

At a time when sexual assault and sexual harassment are pervasive on both college and high school campuses, it’s deeply concerning that President-elect Trump’s pick to head the Department of Education has supported a group that looks to make it more difficult for victims to come forward. Both women and men are at a high risk of being sexually assaulted while in college and they often face barriers to coming forward and reporting incidents, putting others at risk of attack by repeat offenders. Sexual assault is one of the most underreported crimes in our country and we can’t afford to roll back protections for survivors of campus sexual assault. Our focus must be on working to foster a system that supports victims. I’ll continue to advocate on behalf of survivors of sexual assault and work to grow the dialogue about how we can change the culture of sexual assault in our nation. Read more here:

Thank you President Obama for your dignified, hopeful and unifying farewell address. We are grateful for your service these last 8 years, and for the progress you've helped us make as a country. I'll continue working to build on what you've started!

Congresswoman Kuster released the following statement on the nomination of David Shulkin to serve as Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs:  “The men and women who have served our country in uniform deserve the very best support and healthcare we can offer. During my time in office, I’ve been focused on addressing the serious challenges at the Department of Veterans Affairs, and I am committed to continuing to make improvements. We need to increase access to high quality care for all our Veterans and identify ways to expands access to those served in rural communities. David Shulkin has demonstrated his commitment to our Veterans as the Under Secretary of Health at the VA and I’m encouraged by his nomination. I look forward to meeting with Mr. Shulkin to discuss his vision for the future of the VA and how we can work together constructively to improve the system for all Veterans.”

New Hampshire’s character and beauty has always been deeply rooted in our state’s rich agricultural history. As a member of the House Agriculture Committee, I’m committed to supporting our small family farms including dairy farms, which have faced serious challenges in recent years. Read my op-ed in today’s Valley News about my efforts to improve programs that protect our dairy farmers.

Congresswoman Kuster released the following statement on last night’s vote in the Senate to advance a Republican budget that paves the way for repeal of the Affordable Care Act (ACA):  “I’m disappointed that my Republican colleagues in Congress continue to pursue efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act rather than focus on ways to make improvements to the law. I’m one of the first to admit that the ACA isn’t perfect. Few bills are when first passed, but we can’t allow politics to jeopardize the healthcare of millions of Americans, including one-in-ten Granite Staters. I’ve joined my colleagues across the aisle in support of reforms in the past, and I am eager to work together to build on the law and foster a system that works for all Americans.”

Such a moving ceremony today when President Obama surprised Joe Biden with the Presidential Medal of Freedom! Vice President Biden is so deserving of this honor. I'm incredibly thankful to Joe Biden and Dr. Jill Biden for their years of dedicated service to our nation.
Great piece in the Washington Post about the remarkable numbers of Tom Brady. Looking forward to him building on his resume tomorrow night! #GoPats

I’m willing to work with anyone whose goal is to improve our healthcare system. But repealing the Affordable Care Act is the wrong course of action and would jeopardize the healthcare of millions of Americans and one-in-ten Granite Staters. Let’s improve, not repeal. Read my op-ed in the The Concord Monitor today:
On the House floor, I called for bipartisan cooperation to improve the Affordable Care Act. Let's improve, not repeal. Watch here:

Dear Friends,    Today, we honor the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., one of America’s great leaders.    Through the Montgomery Bus Boycott, the March on Washington, the Selma voting rights movement, and more, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. inspired millions to get off the sidelines, speak out, and fight on behalf of justice for all. He taught America that what unites us is far stronger than what divides us. Recent years have tested our resolve to stand as one people, making Dr. King’s message as essential as ever. Each day we should reflect on Dr. King’s lessons of inclusivity and acceptance and apply them to how we treat one another.  I encourage all Americans to keep Dr. King’s legacy of unity, hope, and service alive by coming together with their fellow citizens, looking for common ground, and working for change.    To create change, we must speak up and get involved. I encourage all of you to stand up and make your voice heard. Our future depends on people just like you and I know you will help create a future we can all be proud of.       Sincerely,  Annie

I plan to attend the inauguration of President-elect Trump because we cannot allow our democracy to be hijacked and that requires defending our democratic institutions. I believe in upholding our Constitution and the peaceful transfer of power. I believe in the dignity and sanctity of the Office of the President.   While I have decided to attend the inauguration, I fully support the choice of my colleagues who have reached a different decision. I understand and share the deep frustration of so many of the people in New Hampshire and around the country with the rhetoric and policies of Donald Trump. That is why I will stand in solidarity with hundreds of thousands of Americans at the Women’s March the day after the inauguration. We will in one strong voice denounce the politics of division and hate, call for accountability for Mr. Trump, and demand policies that benefit the many, not the few.
Happy Birthday Michelle Obama! Thank you for your leadership, inspiration, and grace.
Great POLITICO photos of President Obama over the last decade, including one in Concord, NH! Grateful for his dignified service to our country.
For the third year in a row, Earth reached its highest temperature on record. I urge President-elect Donald J. Trump to not ignore climate change and work to protect our planet.

We can’t turn back the clock for women across the country by reducing access to comprehensive affordable healthcare. Defunding Planned Parenthood and repealing the Affordable Care Act will have a real negative impact on women and families in New Hampshire. That’s why I’ve joined with my colleagues to call on President-elect Trump to not undermine women’s health care. The women of America—and the men who care about them—are watching. #ProtectOurCare

“…the Obamas taught us decency, forgiveness, courage — values that are the bedrock of American greatness.” I couldn’t agree more! Thank you for everything, Michelle Obama, Sasha, Malia, and President Obama.

Today I offer my congratulations to Donald Trump on his swearing in as the 45th President of the United States. There are many areas where I have deep concerns about the proposals and rhetoric of President Trump, but I am ready to get to work and focus on the needs of my constituents and our country. I will look to find areas of common ground where we can advance policies to benefit hardworking American families. However, I also stand ready to act as a check against efforts to roll back the progress we have made in recent years. I’m hopeful that following this contentious election, Americans of all stripes will look to find areas of agreement and work to build a nation that supports the many, not just the few.

Today I am standing in solidarity with hundreds of thousands of Americans to—in one strong voice—denounce the politics of division and hate. It’s up to all of us across the nation to send a clear message that we demand a society built on the values of inclusivity and acceptance. We demand that women are paid the same as men and have full reproductive rights, that every American has access to quality, affordable healthcare, that all our children receive a quality education, that our environment is protected for future generations, and we demand policies that benefit the many, not the few.   I’m encouraged and heartened by the collective resolve of the many people standing up for what they believe. We should all strive to create an America where everyone has a place at the table; women, people of color, people of all faiths, members of the LGBTQ community, people with disabilities, survivors of sexual assault, and the countless others who have felt marginalized. I’m proud of the thousands of Granite Staters both here in Washington and in New Hampshire who are defending the values they hold dear. Though we may face challenges, our shared determination will allow us to overcome any hurdle.

So proud of my family members who are taking part in marches across the country today! Together we join with Americans everywhere to denounce the politics of hate & division! Women's March on Washington

Such an amazing display of unity yesterday around the country! So proud of the millions of Americans that stood together for the values they hold dear. I would love to see your photos! Please share your #WomensMarch photos in the comments and tag where they're from.

I’m very disappointed that as one of his first actions as President, Donald Trump will be harming poor women and families in countries that can least afford it. The Global Gag Rule severely limits the ability of international aid organizations to provide comprehensive reproductive healthcare to women around the world and poses a very real threat to our global progress on maternal and child health. The reinstatement of the Global Gag Rule is a clear signal that the Trump Administration does not respect women's reproductive rights and health.
Healthcare is not a game! This reckless approach to dismantling the Affordable Care Act is causing chaos for patients and those seeking affordable health insurance. #ProtectOurCare
So excited to see the New England Patriots headed to their 9th Super Bowl! An amazing accomplishment! #GoPats #DriveForFive

We cannot throw seniors and the most vulnerable under the bus by cutting Social Security and Medicare. President Trump committed to not cutting those programs during the campaign and he should live up to that promise. Balancing the budget on the backs of seniors is simply not an option.

Today I joined my colleagues in the House to express our strong opposition to the Global Gag Rule. This misguided policy will only hurt vulnerable women and families around the world and will lead to an increased number of abortions as a result of less access to family planning services. That’s why I’ve cosponsored legislation to permanently repeal the Global Gag Rule. I’m hopeful that this effort, which has been spearheaded in the Senate by Senator Jeanne Shaheen, can bring people together to support women and families around the globe.

A women’s access to reproductive healthcare should not be determined by her income. The legislation I opposed today would disproportionately impact low income women who are already among our most vulnerable. Taxpayer dollars are prohibited from being used for abortions except in rare cases and this legislation would only make it more difficult for low income women to access affordable private health plans that offer a full range of reproductive healthcare options, including abortion services. This is just a continuation of an extremist Republican agenda aimed at eliminating a woman’s Constitutional right to legal and safe abortion.

Caring for children or a sick relative can pose a real challenge to holding a full-time job. Our country needs commonsense policies that expand childcare options, as well as family and medical leave. Read more here:

Today I'm calling on President Trump to to promptly fill the director position at the Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP). The ONDCP is critical to coordinating the federal response to the opioid epidemic that is hurting communities throughout New Hampshire and the country. During the campaign, President Trump repeatedly expressed his willingness to seriously address the opioid epidemic. I hope he'll honor that commitment.

Joined my colleagues in calling on President Trump to exempt the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs from his hiring freeze on federal civilian employees. This freeze will have a negative impact on veterans and their families.

Today in Keene, I heard from healthcare providers, area leaders, and residents about the importance of the Affordable Care Act and the impact that repealing the law could have on the Monadnock Region. We can't jeopardize the health care of one-in-ten Granite Staters; our focus should be working together to improve the ACA, not repeal it.

Thank you to everyone standing up for women & families at ACLU of New Hampshire last night. We can't turn back the clock on women's reproductive rights and the important progress made since Roe v. Wade 44 years ago.

Thank you to the firefighters, city officials, treatment and healthcare providers, and recovery advocates who sat down with Senator Jeanne Shaheen, Senator Maggie Hassan and I in Nashua today to discuss the importance of the Affordable Care Act in our fight against the opioid epidemic. We can't let politics in Washington destroy the progress we've made in improving access to treatment for so many.

I agree with my colleagues from both sides of the aisle. America can and should be a beacon of hope around the world. I urge President Donald J. Trump to honor the values of inclusion that make us truly great.
Proud to serve with and learn from my colleague Rep. John Lewis about peaceful resistance. Helpful respite from partisan conflict.
My heart goes out to everyone affected by the shooting at a Quebec City mosque. I met with David Alward, Consul General of Canada to New England, to express my condolences to the people of Quebec.

Thank you, University of New Hampshire President Huddleston. Not as Republicans or Democrats, but as Americans, we can balance security and compassion. America was founded on freedom from religious persecution, and I will fight to uphold that freedom and protect our values.
Proud to join my House and Senate colleagues to stand up for our shared American values

Congresswoman Annie Kuster released the following statement on the nomination by President Donald Trump of Judge Neil Gorsuch to serve on the United States Supreme Court:  "I will join all Americans in thoroughly examining Judge Neil Gorsuch's record and judicial philosophy. Any Supreme Court nominee must uphold the rights enshrined in the Constitution as well as the bedrock values we share as Americans. Judge Gorsuch's confirmation could sway the court for a generation, and I have serious concerns about his record on women's rights and his commitment to the many rather than to the few wealthiest Americans and corporate interests. I urge the Senate to thoroughly examine his commitment to our constitutional liberties and his judicial approach to precedent during the confirmation process."

Congresswoman Annie Kuster released the following statement regarding the death of Adam Wright:   "My heart is deeply saddened by the news of the untimely death of Adam Wright, a student at Dartmouth College and the grandson of my dear friends Jim and Susan Wright. As the mother of two recent Dartmouth graduates and an alumna myself, I share in the Dartmouth community’s pain during this difficult time. My husband Brad and I extend our heartfelt condolences to Jim and Susan, their family, and the entire Dartmouth community."

Tonight I’ll be hosting a panel discussion, “Breaking the Silence: A Conversation at the Capitol to Change the Culture and Prevent Sexual Violence.” I’ll be joined by Chessy Prout, Delaney Henderson, Julia Dixon, and Angela Rose of PAVE for a discussion of how, through a national dialogue, education, and legislative action, we can change the culture around sexual assault and end sexual violence. You can also join right here on Facebook Live starting at 7:00PM. Be sure to tune in! Read more in The Concord Monitor:

We'll be Live here on our Facebook page right around 7:00PM with Chessy Prout, Delaney Henderson, Julia Dixon, and Angela Rose of PAVE to discuss #ShatteringTheSilence and ending sexual assault. Please join the discussion!

Join the discussion with Chessy Prout, Delaney Henderson, Julia Dixon, and Angela Rose of PAVE on how through a national dialogue, education, and legislative action, we can shatter the silence and change the culture around sexual assault to end sexual violence. #ShatteringTheSilence

Amazing discussion last night with PAVE-Promoting Awareness Victim Empowerment, Chessy Prout, Delaney Henderson, Julia Dixon, and Angela Rose about breaking the silence and changing the culture around sexual assault. So proud of these courageous young women! #shatteringthesilence #IHaveTheRightTo
Thank you Change Direction New Hampshire for your dedication to erasing the stigma surrounding mental illness. #changementalhealth

Watch the great video introduction of the Biden Foundation, which will work on issues like fighting cancer, supporting military families, standing up for equal rights, and ending violence against women. Thank You Joe Biden and Jill for your continued dedication to improving people’s lives!
Excited to see New England Patriots and Tom Brady make history tonight in Super Bowl 51.  Let’s go Pats!
Hosting a roundtable with the Bipartisan Heroin Task Force on the science and treatment issues behind synthetic opioids, such as fentanyl.  Tune into C-SPAN here to watch:
Congrats to the New England Patriots on an unbelievable team win in Super Bowl 51 last night! New Hampshire is incredibly proud! #GoPats #DriveforFive

Next week is New Hampshire Coalition Against Domestic and Sexual Violence's RESPECT Week to raise awareness of teen dating violence. Each year, nearly 1.5 million high school students experience physical abuse from a dating partner. Learn about ways to support healthy relationships, foster communities of respect in New Hampshire schools, and end teen dating violence here:

No new parent should have to choose between providing for their family and spending important time caring for and fostering the development of a newborn. Similarly, no one should lose their livelihood because they need to care for an ill family member. It’s just not right. We must enact policies that support hardworking families in New Hampshire and around the country with commonsense paid family leave policies. It’s good for families and businesses that will benefit from higher worker retention and less turnover.  Learn more about the Family and Medical Insurance Leave (FAMILY) Act here: http://www.nationalpartnership.org/research-library/work-family/paid-leave/family-act-fact-sheet.pdf

I’m pleased the Senate Committee on Veterans’ Affairs has advanced the nomination of David Shulkin to head the Department of Veterans Affairs. As a member of the House Committee on Veterans’ Affairs, and the lead Democrat on the Subcommittee on Oversights and Investigations, I appreciate the importance of making reforms at the VA to improve care for veterans. Our veterans deserve greater access to the best care possible, and I believe Mr. Shulkin possess the strong leadership required to make necessary reforms to improve the experience of veterans at the VA.

Stifling debate is simply un-American and runs counter to our values. You shouldn't have to be in the majority to voice your opinion. Thank you U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren for your vocal opposition to Senator Sessions' nomination to be Attorney General. #letlizspeak

This week, the Bipartisan Heroin Task Force hosted its first discussion of the negative impact synthetic opioids, such as  fentanyl, are having on New Hampshire and communities around the country. Synthetic opioids have become a serious challenge for healthcare providers and law enforcement. It was fascinating to hear from Dr. Lisa Marsch, Director of the Center for Technology and Behavior at Dartmouth College about her research on this issue.     Learn more here: http://kuster.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/kuster-hears-from-new-hampshire-researcher-on-impact-of-fentanyl

It was an honor to receive the Congressional Leadership Award from CADCA today. I’m committed to continuing to work across the aisle to advance policies to support those on the frontlines of the opioid epidemic. I appreciate the great work of CADCA on bringing together law enforcement, treatment providers, and advocates to educate lawmakers across the country on this crisis.

We must work to remove the stigma surrounding substance use disorder, which prevents so many from getting help. Our words and language matter. Thank you Partnership for a Drug-Free NH for launching the Speak Up campaign to tackle this issue. For more info, visit http://bit.ly/2kvLOjS

The men and women who have served our nation in uniform deserve nothing short of the best care and access to health services possible. That's why I've introduced bipartisan legislation, with my colleague Rep. Jackie Walorski, to make military sexual trauma survivors eligible for benefits to cover expenses when they need to travel long distances to receive treatment.
Great to meet Chelsea Handler today! I look forward to working with her to raise awareness of the need to address the serious issues of sexual assault and substance use disorders. #FightingforAll
Having a blast at the Black Ice Tournament in Concord!

Great New Hampshire Union Leader remembrance of my father's cousin Bill Rotch; Milford Cabinet publisher, WWII veteran and dedicated public servant. Thinking of my cousins Peter Rotch, Martha Manley, Elizabeth Rotch and John Rotch. 100 years of a life well-lived.

Pleased the House has passed the Boosting Rates of American Veteran Employment (BRAVE) Act. It makes sense that contracts awarded by the VA should go to businesses that employ veterans. The men and women who have served our nation in uniform have the skills and experience sought by employers, and encouraging the hiring of veterans not only benefits veterans but also small businesses and our economy. I urge my colleagues in the Senate to act on this commonsense legislation swiftly.

Reports that the White House was aware of the extent of Michael Flynn's conversations with the Russian Ambassador for weeks are extremely troubling. The resignation of Mr. Flynn underscores the importance of transparency in government at a time when we have an Administration that exhibits an unprecedented level of secrecy. The American people deserve to know what the Trump Administration knew and when, as well as the extent of the Administration's ties to Russia and Vladimir Putin. I call on my Congressional colleagues on both sides of the aisle to come together to fully investigate this matter in a swift and thorough manner.

We need a thorough independent investigation into the connection between Russia and President Trump, his campaign, and his advisors. There are too many unanswered questions. Reports that the Trump campaign may have been in touch with Russian intelligence officials prior to the election need to be fully examined by our intelligence community so that the American people can know the truth.

I’ll be hosting a telephone town hall this evening at 6:00 PM to hear from you about what’s on your mind and your priorities for the coming year. Call (855) 756-7520 Ext. 34535# to take part in the conversation.

Title X is critical in ensuring women and families in need have access to affordable contraception and family planning services.  I’ll fight efforts to dismantle this essential program and create roadblocks to receiving care.

Repealing the Affordable Care Act would make deep cuts to substance abuse and mental health treatment, leaving significantly more people unable to access the care they need. We need to work together to strengthen care for those struggling with substance misuse disorders and mental health issues.

I just voted against a misguided Republican proposal to weaken the Title X national family planning program by rolling back a Title X rule designed to shield family planning clinics across the country from partisan state-level defunding efforts. This is nothing more than a thinly veiled attack on the ability of low income women and their families to access comprehensive family planning services. We’ve seen firsthand here in New Hampshire that partisan politics can interfere with care for thousands of Granite State women, men, and their families. We should be working to expand access to comprehensive family planning services, not jeopardizing care for the most vulnerable among us.

This morning, on the last day of New Hampshire Coalition Against Domestic and Sexual Violence RESPECT Week, I met with students at Milford High School to thank them for pledging their commitment to fostering and upholding a culture of respect in their school and community. #RespectWeekNH
Nashua Safe Stations are doing remarkable work to provide a path to treatment for people with substance use disorder.  Watch the new PSA here:  http://bit.ly/2lvNdYS
Congratulations to the 2nd District's own Mikaela Shiffrin, who won another world championship in slalom!
Thank you to our community nurses who play a vital role here in New Hampshire and elsewhere.

I was excited to announce the introduction of my STEM in Early Education bill today at the Child and Family Development Center at NHTI, Concord's Community College with early educators and STEM stakeholders in attendance. I urge my colleagues in the House to pass this legislation, which will create a grant program for early childhood STEM activities, so we can best ensure hands-on learning for our future workforce and economy.

Congresswoman Kuster released the following statement on the dramatic price increase of naloxone injector Evzio from $690 to $4,500 for a pack of two:   “First responders, firefighters, police, and treatment providers are doing incredible work to save lives and help those struggling with substance use disorder. What we can’t afford is for those on the frontlines of this crisis to have a life-saving tool taken from them. The simplicity of Naloxone has saved thousands of lives in New Hampshire and its continued availability is critical to preventing overdose deaths. I’m very concerned about this astronomical price increase and will work with my colleagues to ensure that naloxone and lifesavings drugs are available to address the opioid crisis.”   Read more here:

Congresswoman Kuster released the following statement on Dr. Omid Moghimi’s reunion with his wife, Dorsa Razi, an Iranian citizen who traveled to the United States after President Donald Trump’s executive order on immigration was blocked:   “I am thrilled to see Dr. Moghimi reunite with his wife after the past few difficult weeks. America should serve as a beacon of hope around the world and President Trump’s executive action is counter to our very values as a nation. I am proud to have helped bring this young couple back together, and I will continue to defend the values of acceptance and inclusion that make American truly great.”

I commend the University of New Hampshire on their announcement of the Granite Guarantee, which will provide free tuition to full-time, first-year New Hampshire students who are receiving federal Pell grants.  For too many Granite State students and families, the rising cost of tuition has put a higher education degree out of reach.  UNH’s commitment to help 285 first-year students break down this financial barrier represents a significant investment in our students and future workforce. I applaud UNH’s leadership in making college more affordable for low-income Granite State students.

Thank you to the healthcare providers, advocates and state lawmakers from the Upper Valley who sat down with me today in Lebanon to discuss how we can best continue to come together to speak out on the positive impact of the Affordable Care Act on rural communities.

Great to tour Canam-Bridges’ Claremont plant today to discuss the new border preclearance law I helped pass late last year.  This law will boost trade and economic development in Claremont and around New Hampshire by allowing rail, air and boat passengers to pass through Customs and Border Patrol inspections prior to traveling, instead of stopping at the Canadian border.
In case you missed it: great article in The Eagle Times about my visit to Canam-Bridges' Claremont plant yesterday to discuss the new border preclearance law.

The words of New Hampshire’s James Foley are as true now as ever, “If I don’t have the moral courage to challenge authority. . . we don’t have journalism.”  I’m glad his words were shared with the world last night. We will never forget Foley’s courage and dedication to the pursuit of truth.

I’m wearing white to tonight’s #jointsession with my colleagues and my friend Congresswoman Katherine Clark to honor the suffragettes and let the President know that the women of America are watching. I’m ready to stand for women’s reproductive rights, equal pay for equal work, paid family leave and affordable childcare, high quality education for all Americans, and access to quality affordable healthcare. #WomenWearWhite

Honored to be joined by Sue Messinger of Holderness, NH at tonight's Joint Session of Congress. Since the tragic passing of her son, Sue has been an incredible advocate for those seeking to overcome substance misuse disorders, and I hope her presence this evening will reminder the President of the importance of continuing to support treatment and recovery efforts.

This evening, I listened as President Trump outlined his vision for America, and I hope he now moves away from the politics of division that have been a hallmark of his campaign and time in office. As we know the Devil is in the details, and I will carefully examine President Trump's proposals as they are put forward. I stand ready to seek areas of common ground to advance policies shared by both Republicans and Democrats. We can address the opioid epidemic, we can fix our roads and bridges, we can improve care for our veterans, and we can support families with commonsense paid family leave. But we can only do these things if we sit down and work together. I’m ready to do so, I hope Republicans are too.  However, I will not stand by quietly if the Administration puts the interests of the few ahead of the many. We must fully investigate Trump's conflicts of interest to ensure our country is always put before business. We cannot turn back the clock on the progress we have made. We must defend the values of inclusivity and acceptance that make America truly great. We cannot jeopardize the healthcare of thousands of Granite Staters by recklessly repealing the Affordable Care Act. I'm committed to protecting the rights of women to make their own healthcare decisions. I'm committed to strengthening Social Security and Medicare for our seniors, and I'm committed to ensuring that members of the LGBTQ community are safe from discrimination.

Women’s History Month is a time for us to honor and thank the amazing women who regardless of the headwinds have, are, and will make history. Today I’m thinking of my great-grandmother, Susan Bancroft, who served as president of the Concord Woman’s Club, the Concord Female Charitable Society, and the Concord Equal Suffrage League in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. President Trump’s preliminary budget proposal is simply a disaster for our economy, environment, seniors, and hardworking families in New Hampshire and across the country. This budget proposal should raise red flags for anyone who wants to grow our middle class, create good paying jobs, protect human health and our environment, and fight climate change. We can’t turn back the clock on the progress we’ve made in recent years to get our economy pointed in the right direction and this budget is little more than a return to the same failed policies of the past. President Trump needs to seriously reconsider this approach and focus on crafting a budget proposal that benefits all Americans, not just those at the very top.   In New Hampshire, we know the serious impact toxic contamination can have on drinking water, public health, and quality of life. Slashing thirty one percent of the Environmental Protection Agency’s budget will only make defending public health and our environment more difficult. Cutting the Department of Health and Human Services by thirteen percent will eliminate the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) and harm programs like Meals on Wheels and home visits that our seniors and low-income families rely on. This budget cuts the Department of Agriculture by more than twenty percent, reducing support for our small family farms, rural development programs, and the National Forest System. Investing in our children is one of the most important ways we can ensure a brighter future for our nation. A fourteen percent cut to the Department of Education just doesn’t make sense.  Eliminating Community Development Block Grants will hurt the ability of our communities to plan and invest in the future.  Weatherization programs are critical in New Hampshire and cuts to the Department of Energy would eliminate the Weatherization Assistance Program entirely. These are just a few examples of the many negative impacts this budget would have on New Hampshire. I strongly oppose this preliminary budget proposal, and for the benefit of our country, I urge my colleagues to do the same.

The the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program is a lifeline for low-income families and seniors in the Granite State during the cold winter months and the elimination of such a successful and necessary program is cruel. President Trump’s budget proposal would hit rural communities that can least afford it the hardest and jeopardize the economic progress that has been made in the North Country. Simply put, this budget proposal is wrong for the North Country, wrong for New Hampshire, and wrong for our country.

Last night’s strike by U.S. Forces against Assad’s airpower appears to be an appropriate response to Assad’s gruesome slaughter of his own people. The women who were targeted have dedicated their lives to protecting our country, and sharing sexually explicit photos of them is not only a blatant disregard to their privacy, but it also undermines our national security and puts these women at risk of blackmail, violence, or worst. Today marks 73 years since brave American and Allied troops stormed the beaches of Normandy and began the assault to liberate Europe from unspeakable evil and Tyranny. My father Malcolm McLane flew over the beaches of Normandy on D-Day. You can read a letter he wrote home days after the invasion that appeared in the Concord Monitor on June 6, 2004:  Overcast or not, it's time to fly   Malcolm McLane, now a Concord lawyer, joined the Army Air Force in 1943. On June 6, 1944, he was a 19-year-old fighter pilot stationed in England near the shortest route across the English Channel to France. Almost immediately after Lt. McLane took off (he flew 72 missions in all), he could see the coast of France. His job on D-Day was to patrol the landing beaches in his single-seat P-47 Thunderbolt and challenge any German planes that tried to strafe the Allied assault force. This proved unnecessary, as the Germans, apparently fooled about where and when the invasion was coming, did not contest the landing from the air. A few days later, McLane wrote a letter to his family describing his bird's-eye glimpse of the great invasion. Here is that letter:  By MALCOLM McLANE  For the Monitor  It's three o'clock, Tuesday morning, June 6, 1944. Someone is shaking you in your blanket roll, but you're too sleepy to get up, for you didn't get to bed until midnight and it was after one before the talking quieted down and you got to sleep.  Then the bright light goes on in your face, and you remember what you were told in that three-hour-long, secret briefing last night: "Today is D-Day!"  You tumble out as best you can, put on extra socks and heavy shoes from force of habit, for someday you may have to walk back. There's some hot coffee and an egg in the mess tent, then you pile into jeeps and trucks and hurry to the line, where the ground crews have already been warming up the planes.  There's your Mae West to put on, your helmet and goggles and chute to put in the plane, before you pack into the squadron briefing tent and get courses and instructions regarding your mission.  There's no comment on the weather, as there usually is, for it's obviously terrible. Ordinarily the mission would be scratched, but there's no canceling this one.  Fifteen minutes before start-engine time, you're in your plane checking everything and getting buckled in. It's still dark, for the sun isn't due to rise for over an hour and there won't be much twilight with this solid overcast and misty rain with its low ceiling and visibility.  Belly tanks cause some trouble as you taxi out, but there's no waiting for stragglers. Those who can make it are off the ground and circling over the field, trying to get into formation. It's no easy thing, and many wander home alone. Once you've set course, you must climb up through the overcast on instruments.  The formation breaks up even more, and when you break out on top, headed into a full moon and a clear sky, you find yourself alone on your element leader's wing. The rest have popped up through the blanket of clouds on their own and are doing their best to find the patrol area separately. Navigation is a matter of compass headings and timing, for there are no landmarks here over this ocean of white.  To the east the sky gets lighter all the time. After an hour occasional breaks appear below, and the two of you spiral down to reconnoiter. It's France all right, but where? A radio call and a fix, and soon you're given a heading to target.  Below the clouds it's murky again, but the light behind you is getting pinker and the fleecy clouds at the bottom of the overcast are a lovely soft red. Below, ships begin to appear, their guns flashing in the darkness, while the rising sun brings out their forms gradually and makes the water a deep red. The air is still misty and the visibility poor, but this only adds to the sun's reddish glare.  For another hour you patrol back and forth over the beachhead-to-be as the big guns pound away. And then when you're about to leave - your gas is getting low - a little fleet of boats leaves the great fleet offshore, passes the outermost ring of destroyers and heads for the beaches.  As you head back across the channel to England, the scattered small wakes of the landing craft move toward the shore. In another few minutes the invasion will have begun.  More planes will relieve you, and many more ships will follow those first boats, but that hour before H-hour will be a never-forgotten memory of this war, whose other details I will willingly forget. My part was nil, for there was no opposition from the air, but our mission was carried out and the beachhead won.  Copyright (c) 2004 Concord Monitor

Senate Republicans have crafted a cruel healthcare bill behind closed doors that would threaten access to healthcare for thousands of Granite Staters and millions of Americans. This misguided legislation would be a disaster for hardworking families in New Hampshire and cannot be allowed to become law. I’m eager to work across the aisle to repair, not repeal the Affordable Care Act. There are members of Congress, both Republican and Democrat, who want to work in a bipartisan way to make constructive improvements to the Affordable Care Act to expand access to care and lower costs. It’s long past time Republican leadership abandon its single-minded focus on repealing the Affordable Care Act and instead got down to the hard work of actually improving our healthcare delivery system for all Americans.

I’m pleased that the VA Accountability Act has been signed into law. We need to ensure that employees who impede the mission of the VA are held accountable and this bipartisan legislation is an important step toward making that a reality. The provisions of my amendment that were included will help to improve protections for whistleblowers, allowing them to come forward more readily if they see something wrong. This legislation is an example of how when we work across the aisle we can make important progress for our veterans and our nation. I was honored to watch Speaker of the House Paul Ryan sign the bill before sending it to the president.

Today I joined Dr. Brian Sites and John Broderick of Dartmouth-Hitchcock, Annette Escalante, Vice President of Keystone Hall treatment center, and Steven Galipeau, Chief of the Nashua Fire Department to discuss the impact repealing the ACA would have on access to mental health and substance use treatment in New Hampshire. Dr. Sites recently authored a groundbreaking study detailing the extent of opioid prescribing for people with mental illness.  With the intense political debate going on in Washington over healthcare, it’s easy to lose sight of the fact that this is ultimately about real people. The Affordable Care Act gave Granite Staters access to healthcare, and it guaranteed that essential benefits would be covered in their plans. The importance of having access to mental health services and substance use treatment cannot be overstated. Sadly, the Republican healthcare bills would strip the requirement that these services be included in coverage. We know there are improvements that can be made to our current system, but we can’t do this at the expense of those who need this care the most.

I hope that this most recent analysis will encourage my Republican colleagues to come to the table to work on real solutions for people in New Hampshire and across the country.”

President Trump’s voter commission has been formed with the predetermined conclusion that voter fraud is a widespread problem and that restrictive voter ID laws are necessary to safeguard our democracy. At a time when the opioid epidemic is impacting communities across the country, it’s critical that no tools are taken off the table. We know that the opioid crisis has in part been fueled by the over prescribing of opioid pain medications and any limitations on the DEA’s ability to get unneeded prescription drugs off the street must be eliminated. I’m pleased that Rep. Evan Jenkins, Congressman Tim Ryan, Jim Cooper and I have been able to come together in a bipartisan fashion to introduce legislation to repeal provisions of the Ensuring Patient Access and Effective Drug Enforcement Act, which DEA officials cite as restricting their ability to do their job.

The opioid crisis has hit countless communities across the country and it leaves no demographic untouched. For Congressman Tom MacArthur, Donald Norcross, Congressman Tim Ryan and I--the leaders of the Bipartisan Heroin Task Force--virtually every one of our constituents has a family member or knows a friend who has suffered from the perils of opioid addiction. A national emergency declaration by President Trump could provide the federal government additional tools it could use to help communities across the country grapple with this disease. While this declaration would be an important step, the president’s cooperation with Congress to provide the necessary funding to properly support such an emergency declaration is critical. We urge President Trump to work with Congress in a bipartisan fashion to advance emergency supplemental funding as well as legislative proposals similar to those proposed in our legislative agenda and his own Commission on Combating Drug Addiction and the Opioid Crisis findings. Read our full letter urging President Trump to declare the opioid crisis a national emergency here:

At this special time of year, it’s important to remember what the holiday season is all about: giving to others, practicing gratitude, reflecting on the year behind us, and looking to the year ahead with hope. Today and always, I especially want to express my gratitude to the men and women who are spending the holidays away from family serving to defend our freedoms.   As we gather with our families, friends and loved ones to celebrate the season and the start of 2018, let us take a moment to reach out to our neighbors and spread the warmth of the season to all. Simply offering a smile, a warm meal or a helping hand with everyday tasks can make a world of difference.  Though this past year has been marked by much partisan division, I have focused on working together with all my colleagues to get real results for all Granite Staters. I’ve had legislation signed into law that will address challenges at the Department of Veterans Affairs and improve our response to the opioid epidemic. I’m working to boost jobs and our economy through expanded trade and tourism with Canada. We’ve come together, both Republican and Democrat, to begin to change the all too prevalent culture of sexual harassment and assault. And we’ve pushed back against efforts to threaten the healthcare of millions of Americans and thousands of people in New Hampshire.  Over the past year, thousands of you have written to my office or called to share your ideas and concerns. Hearing all of you speak out in favor of fairness, justice, and helping those in need leaves me hopeful for the coming year. I’ll continue to fight for you and for everyone in the Granite State.  Thank you for everything you do to make New Hampshire such a wonderful place to live. I hope you have a great holiday and happy New Year!

We know that a comprehensive approach is necessary to take on the opioid epidemic that's impacting communities throughout New Hampshire and the country. That means expanding treatment and recovery services and also supporting law enforcement. The INTERDICT Act which has now passed Congress will help US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) reduce the flow of fentanyl and synthetic opioids from outside the country by giving CBP the necessary tools to detect and intercept these dangerous substances. I am pleased that the agenda of the Bipartisan Heroin Task Force is continuing to advance and I urge the President to sign this commonsense legislation that will help keep our country safe.
